You should not drink milk after eating fish of a few particular species in a few particular months. Because in their breeding season their body chemicals change and there is a … chemical present which reacts with milk and skin pigmentation problems do arise in human beings.

1. I heard from several people that drinking milk or dairy products while eating fish can lead towards a special skin pigmentation disorders such as different skin color or bright spots on skin. I asked a dermatologist about it and she said it is preferred not to do so, as there are some cases reported. The skin disease particulars you mention above seems to be an elaboration from Hindu religion: In Pakistan, it is widely believed that if one drinks milk after eating fish (or other way around), you get skin disease. However this is not true. The skin disease (in which people's skin become white overtime) is a tropical skin disease and has nothing to do with simultaneous consumption of fish and milk

This is a common Indian myth that having milk products over chicken and fish will cause white patches on the skin. This was thought so in the olden days, but today, there is no scientific proof connecting skin color to the foods we eat. The most common reason to have skin patches is Leucoderma. Consider that there are thousands of tasty recipes in which fish are cooked with or in milk, have toppings that include milk in some form, and that many people world-wide have consumed milk with or immediately after fish for as long as several thousand years and in virtually all parts of the world.
There is no reason not to drink milk after eating fish, I often poach fish in milk and use the milk to make some parsley sauce.
